assessment.title: Anatomy and Direction of the Cardiovascular System

body.p: What direction best describes the location of the heart relative to the shoulders?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Superficial means closer to the surface (skin) relative to the bone (deep).
Correct. The heart is between the shoulders, slightly to the left of the center.
Incorrect. Distal means further away from the axis in the appendicular portion of the body.
Incorrect. Lateral would indicate that the heart is located toward the sides of the shoulders.

no_response.feedback: Please try to answer the question.

part.hint: The heart is slightly off-center (to the left) in the body, but is still in between the shoulders.

question.body: Where is the heart located relative to the sternum?

response.feedback: Correct. The heart is posterior to (behind) the sternum.
Incorrect. The heart is not in front of the sternum.
Incorrect. The heart is not toward the side of the sternum.

Incorrect. In order for an organ to be described as "intermediate," its position must be noted in relation to two other structures, because when used to denote location, "intermediate" means "between." Only the sternum is mentioned in this question.

no_response.feedback: Please try to answer the question.

part.hint: The sternum, or breastbone, is at the front of the chest; it is where gorillas beat their fists.

question.body: Where is the heart relative to the digestive organs?

response.feedback: Correct. The heart is superior to (above) the digestive organs.
Incorrect. The heart is within the trunk of the body.
Incorrect. The heart is anterior to the spinal column and above the digestive organs.
Incorrect. The heart is above most of the digestive organs.

no_response.feedback: Please try to answer the question.

part.hint: The heart is in the chest and most of the digestive organs are in the middle and lower abdomen.
